author: Deleted User
content:
Hey guys, so a friend of mine raised a query about the implications of stable coins, if and when ETH chain ia forked by say CIRCLE (which issues usdc), since circle is under control of regulators, they can launch a forked ETH, declare usdc tokens on eth chain are not redeemable but are redeemable on the forked chain. With this forked chain, they can comply with all regulatory requirements and modify the codes and setup their own initial nodes. Now the DeFi protocols have no choice but to go with CIRCLE's backed forked ETH Chain. Seeing defi development on forked ETH of circle, miners/stakers will gradually shift to fETH chain. This basically opens up a centralisation problem all over again.

Would love to hear your thoughts on this. Thanks. :)

author: chris2_2_2
content: You just invented binance smart chain.

author: andi9314
content: Well presumably regulators will like fETH. They hate binance.

author: Deleted User
content: Im more concerned how circle has this power to declare which chain's coins are redeemable.

author: andi9314
content: It seems reasonable that stablecoins could be used as a gateway or leverage for regulators. Although regulators may be okay with ETH being unregulated as long as the stablecoin issuers are regulated. The wording of Beyer's proposed bill seemed to suggest this, but I'm not sure.

author: busypanda
content: the gov are ok with a chain with kyc at every level. And if circle faces pressure they will gladly move their business to such a place. Circle is the one holding people's dollar. They have the leverage to dictate

author: busypanda
content: This should be something of a concern imo especially after seeing how hostile gov have gotten regarding to de fi
